8274 ALTIMG MCAT 114870 114870 S2468-8231(25)00056-2 10.1016/j.mcat.2025.114870 The Author(s) Fig. 1 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the bare SA support (a), as well as the passivated catalysts FeP/SA (b) and freshly reduced Fe/SA (c). The Fe/SA sample was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen, then activated with syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 cm3 min−1) at room temperature. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 X-ray diffraction patterns of the bare SA support (a), as well as the passivated catalysts FeP/SA (b) and freshly reduced Fe/SA (c). The Fe/SA sample was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen, then activated with syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 cm3 min−1) at room temperature. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Fe 2p core-level spectra of active catalysts (a) and P 2p core-level spectra of active FeP/SA catalysts (b). The Fe/SA sample was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen, then activated with syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 cm3 min−1) at room temperature. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 HRTEM image (a), representative general image (b), elemental mappings (c), and corresponding spectral composition (d) of the active FeP/SA catalysts. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 mL min−1) at room temperature. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Time on-stream behavior of the active catalysts in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. Reaction conditions: 280 °C; P = 20 bar; H2/CO = 2; GHSV = 4800 m l g c a t − 1 h − 1 . The Fe/SA sample was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen, then activated with syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 mL min−1) at room temperature. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 X-ray diffraction patterns of spent catalysts after 78 h of FTS reaction; FeP/SA (a) Fe/SA (b). Before the data acquisition, the spent catalysts were treated at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 200 cm3 min−1 flow of ultra-high purity nitrogen to eliminate volatile and adsorbed compounds. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 HRTEM image (a-b), elemental mappings (b) and representative general image (c) for spent FeP/SA catalysts after 78 h of FTS reaction. Before the data acquisition, the spent catalysts were treated at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 200 cm3 min−1 flow of ultra-high purity nitrogen to eliminate volatile and adsorbed compounds. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Fe 2p core-level spectra (a) and C 1 s core-level spectra (b) of the spent catalysts after FTS at TOS of 78 h. Prior to XPS measurements, spent catalysts were treated differently for Fe 2p and P 2p core levels and C 1 s spectra acquisition. For Fe 2p and P 2p core levels, the samples were treated at 120 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of ultra-high purity nitrogen to remove volatile compounds. For C 1 s spectra acquisition, the spent catalysts were treated at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 200 cm3 min−1 flow of ultra-high purity nitrogen to eliminate volatile and adsorbed compounds. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 CO conversion as a function of temperature during the water shift reaction on the active catalysts. Reaction conditions: Atmospheric pressure; H2O/CO/N2 (5/2.5/92.5); GHSV = 4800 m l g c a t − 1 h − 1 . The Fe/SA sample was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen, then activated with syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The FeP/SA catalyst was activated at 650 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1), followed by passivation with 0.5 % O2/N2 (100 mL min−1) at room temperature. Prior to analysis, the spent catalysts were treated at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 200 cm3 min−1 flow of ultra-high purity nitrogen to eliminate volatile and adsorbed compounds. Insights into active iron phosphide as Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst for sustainable light olefins production T.A. Zepeda Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Centro de Nanociencias y Nanotecnología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Km. 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada, C. P. 22800, Ensenada, Mexico Centro de Nanociencias y Nanotecnología Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México Km. 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada, C. P Ensenada 22800 Mexico Centro de Nanociencias y Nanotecnología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Km. 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada, C. P. 22800, Ensenada, Mexico Here reports preliminary results on the performance of iron phosphide-based catalysts supported on SiO2-Al2O3 (denoted as SA) for sustainable light olefin production via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, compared to conventional iron-based catalysts. Characterization results confirmed the presence of a well-defined FeP phase in the iron phosphide-based catalysts (FeP/SA), whereas the iron-based catalysts (Fe/SA) displayed a mixture of metallic iron (Fe0), oxidized iron (Fe+2/Fe+3), and Hägg iron carbide phase (χ-Fe5C2). The FeP/SA catalyst exhibited significantly higher CO conversion and stability over long reaction times, attributed to its resistance to surface iron species reoxidation, lower loss of exposed surface Fe species, and lower coke formation during the FTS reaction. The FeP/SA catalyst exhibited higher selectivity toward light olefins formation (C2 ⁻- C4 ⁻), while reducing selectivity for methane (CH4) and heavier hydrocarbon formation compared to the Fe/SA catalyst. Furthermore, FeP/SA exhibited lower selectivity to CO2 formation, which may indicate reduced water-gas shift (WGS) activity or the oxidation of adsorbed CO by surface-bound oxygen, resulting from the direct dissociation of CO on the surface, compared to Fe/SA catalyst. These results suggest that iron phosphide-based catalysts provide an efficient alternative for hydrocarbon production in FTS, particularly in the selective formation of light olefins. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal phosphides Iron phosphide Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Carbon monoxide Removable fuels Syngas conversion Light olefins Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Valorizing carbon oxides into value-added chemicals and fuels presents a viable solution for mitigating carbon emissions and reducing fossil fuel consumption, advancing in the circular carbon economy [1,2]. Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) provides an attractive and sustainable method for producing renewable fuels and valuable industrial chemicals compounds through CO hydrogenation [3]. Cobalt and iron are the most widely used catalysts due to their catalytic selectivity and cost [4,5]. Cobalt-based catalysts provide high conversion rates, resistance to deactivation, and lower CO2 formation [6,7]. However, they have a limited temperature range, with challenges in controlling long-chain hydrocarbon and oxygenate growth [7,8]. In contrast, iron-based catalysts offer a more economical alternative, operating across a broader operating range of temperatures and producing a diverse range of light to medium-heavy hydrocarbons compared to cobalt-based catalysts [9,10]. However, the iron based catalysts are prone to coke deposition and iron carbide formation, leading to undesirable side reactions [11,12]. Additionally, iron catalysts are more vulnerable to oxidation by water and carbon dioxide generated during the reaction [4,12,13]. Therefore, exploring new, more stable active phases of iron-based catalysts for FTS is necessary. Recently, transition metal phosphides (e.g., Ni2P, NiP, Co2P, CoP, MoP, WP, FeP) have garnered significant attention as promising catalysts due to their high activity and stability across various catalytic reactions, even in the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide [14–17]. Transition metal phosphides possess unique geometric structures in which metal atoms are effectively separated by phosphorus atoms [18]. The insertion of phosphorus atoms into the metal lattice alters the electronic properties and adsorption behavior of the transition metal, due to the ligand and ensemble effects [19]. This configuration enhances their catalytic performance, as the presence of phosphorus increases the electron density of the transition metal, increasing the metallicity property [20,21]. These metallic characteristics are key to the high activity observed in various catalytic reactions, making transition metal phosphides highly effective catalysts [20]. These structures have been shown through both experimental and theoretical investigations to exhibit excellent resistance to coke formation and reoxidation of the active phase [22,23]. Researchers have even suggested that phosphide catalysts possess catalytic properties like those of precious metals, explaining their remarkable resistance to sulfur poisoning [24,25]. These characteristics suggest that transition metal phosphide-based catalysts could be highly efficient for syngas conversion. The exceptional hydrogen dissociation and hydrogenation abilities of the Ni2P phase have prompted studies into its use in CO2 hydrogenation and CO2 methanation [16,26]. Research has revealed that Ni2P exhibits strong resistance to carbon deposition in the dry reforming of methane, a common issue that typically leads to deactivation in most CO2 conversion reactions [16,26]. Q. Zhang et al. [16] reported the activity of nickel phosphides catalysts for CO2 conversion in combined CO2 methanation and RWGS reactions. The study demonstrated that these Ni phosphide catalysts exhibited high CO2 conversion efficiency and remarkable selectivity toward the desired end products, CH4 and CO. Even at low temperatures, methanation was favored, while significant selectivity toward CO was also observed. S. Bao et al. [27] reported that the product selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation can be significantly shifted from CH4 to CO by phosphating SiO2-supported Ni catalysts, attributed to the geometric effect. Both Ni12P5 and Ni2P crystalline phases exhibited strong catalytic activity, with Ni12P5 being notably more active in CO2 conversion via a direct CO2 dissociation pathway, where adsorbed CO serves as a key intermediate. However, the weak interaction of CO with the nickel phosphide phase explains the low selectivity toward methane formation. B.-W. Wang et al. [28] investigated the catalytic activity of various metal phosphides, including MoP, WP, CoP, and NiP, in syngas methanation. Among them, the MoP-PA catalyst demonstrated significantly higher activity compared to the other phosphides Have et al. [29] studied the effect of supports and promoters on the performance of MoP catalysts in syngas conversion, focusing on selectivity towards higher alcohol formation. An excess of phosphorus, along with the presence of potassium, promoted the formation of the MoP phase on an amorphous silica support. However, cobalt and nickel acted as inhibitors rather than promoters, while palladium increased CO conversion but favored the production of shorter-chain alcohols. S. Xiangen et al. [17] reported the synthesis of mixed alcohols from CO hydrogenation using iron and nickel phosphide catalysts. FePx catalysts primarily yielded mixed oxygenated compounds, while NiPx catalysts favored methanol production. The Fe2P and Fe3P phases demonstrated stability during CO hydrogenation, unlike the metallic iron catalyst, which largely converted into iron carbide. Similarly, the Ni2P, Ni3P, and Ni12P5 phases, along with the metallic Ni catalyst, remained stable throughout the CO hydrogenation process. Y. Jinghe et al. [30] reported the catalytic activity of a graphene-supported FeP catalyst in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The catalyst demonstrated good CO conversion and maintained high stability throughout 20 h of evaluation. It exhibited low selectivity for CO2 formation while favoring the production of C2 C4 hydrocarbons, with selectivity for heavier compounds (C5 +) reaching up to 10 %. The authors reported that the FeP phase displayed structural stability and resistance to coke formation, carbonization, and reoxidation of the active phase. Despite this, there has been limited research on the catalytic applications of transition metal phosphides in the conversion of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide [21], particularly in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. This study reports the catalytic activity of iron phosphide catalyst supported on mesoporous SiO2-Al2O3 material in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis towards the synthesis of light olefins. The choice of an Al2O3-SiO2 support addresses the need for a material that combines the thermal stability of Al2O3 with the favorable properties of SiO2 for the performance of phosphide catalysts, such as the inert nature and compatibility with phosphide phases. Given that iron phosphides have been underexplored in such applications, this work aims to ignite interest within the catalysis community to further explore these catalysts for converting carbon oxides into value-added products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the mesoporous Al2O3–SiO2 mixed oxide The mesoporous Al2O3–SiO2 mixed oxide support was synthesized at a 2:1 molar ratio. First, 1 g of Pluronic triblock copolymer P123 ((EO)20(PO)70(EO)20, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in 20 cm3 of anhydrous ethanol (99.99 %) under vigorous stirring for 4 h until fully dissolved. In a separate solution, 10 mmol of aluminum isopropoxide was dissolved in a mixture of 1.6 cm3 nitric acid (67 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and 5.0 cm3 anhydrous ethanol. Next, the required amount of tetraethyl orthosilicate (98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was added dropwise to the aluminum isopropoxide solution with continuous stirring for 5 h. After solvent evaporation at 30 °C in air, the solid was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 750 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis Iron-based phosphide catalysts (10 wt.% Fe) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the Al2O3–SiO2 support using iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate and phosphorous acid (H2PO3H) to achieve a P/Fe molar ratio of 1, following the method described by E. Rodríguez-Aguado [31] for the specific synthesis of the FeP phase. The impregnated sample was dried at 60 °C for 24 h, and the oxidic precursors were then reduced ex-situ under a hydrogen flow of 1000 cm3 gcat −1 min−1 in a tubular reactor. The reduction process began with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 300 °C, followed by a slower heating rate of 3 °C min−1, holding at 650 °C for 2.5 h. After reduction, the catalysts were cooled to room temperature under helium flow and then passivated in 100 cm3 min−1 of 0.5 % O2/N2 (Infra) for 4 h at room temperature. As a reference, a phosphate-free Iron-based catalyst (10 wt.% Fe) was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the Al2O3–SiO2 support using iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate. The sample was dried at 60 °C for 24 h, then calcined at 400 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The sample was reduced in a tubular reactor under a 100 cm3 min−1 flow of 20 % hydrogen-nitrogen at 450 °C for 2 h, then activated with 100 cm³ min−1 of syngas (H2/CO = 2) at 400 °C for 4 h, both with a 5 °C/min heating rate. 2.3 Characterization methods The chemical composition was quantified using an Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-AES) Perkin Elmer Optima 3300DV instrument. Textural properties were evaluated using the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C on a Micromeritics TRISTAR III system. Before the analysis, samples were pre-treated by outgassing at 200 °C for 10 h. X-ray diffraction measurements were performed using a PANalytical Aeris diffractometer outfitted with a Pixel 1D detector and a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5405 Å), with a step size of 0.021 °/min, in the 2θ range of 10 to 60 °. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired using a SPECS® spectrometer with a PHOIBOS® 150 9MCD 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with sub-degree angular resolution (< 0.5 °), equipped with XR 50 Al-X-ray source for Al/Mg excitation lines. Charge-related effects were adjusted by setting the C 1 s peak binding energies of adventitious carbon to 284.5 eV. The nature of the acid sites of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated by FTIR spectroscopy of the adsorbed pyridine using a Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrometer. To remove hydrocarbons, permanent gases and adsorbed water on the surface, the samples were first dried at 500 °C under ultra-high purity Ar flux (99.999 %) for 1 h. The amount of coke deposited on the catalysts was determined using a TGA/SDTA851 thermogravimetric equipment (Mettler Toledo) by measuring the weight losses after oxi-dation of the coked catalysts. To remove hydrocarbons, permanent gases and adsorbed water on the surface, the samples were first dried at 500 °C under ultra-high purity Ar flux (99.999 %) for 1 h. Next, coke combustion was carried out by raising the sample temperature to a final temperature of 1150 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1 in a 20 % O2/N2 gas mixture. Metal dispersion was determined through CO-chemisorption measurements using a Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar equipment. Before measurement, the samples were activated following the procedure outlined in the catalyst synthesis section. The chemisorption isotherm was obtained by measuring the amount of CO adsorbed between 10 and 600 mmHg at 35 °C. After the initial analysis, the reversibly adsorbed gas was evacuated, and the analysis was repeated to quantify the chemisorbed amounts. D i s p e r s i o n ( % ) = C O U p t a k e ( m m o l e s g − 1 ) M e t a l l o a d i n g ( m m o l e s g − 1 ) TEM images of the samples were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100F (STEM) microscope with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), operating at 200 kV and 54 μA. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements Fischer–Tropsch synthesis was carried out in a tubular fixed-bed reactor at 280 °C, 20 atm, with an H2/CO ratio of 2. Catalyst grains were sieved to obtain a fraction of 0.25–0.50 mm. Approximately 200 mg of each catalyst was loaded into the catalytic reactor and activated following the procedure outlined in the catalyst synthesis section. The samples were heated to the reaction temperature of 250 °C under a flow of high-purity argon at a rate of 5 °C min−1, after which the reaction mixture of H2/CO/N2 (62/31/7 molar ratio, with N2 as an internal standard) was introduced at a flow to obtain an GHSV of 4800 c m 3 g c a t − 1 h − 1 . The pressure was raised to 20 atm and maintained isobarically throughout the reaction. The temperature was increased up to 320 °C at 5 °C min−1. Reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography. Permanent gases (N2, H2, CO, CO2, and CH4) were monitored online via a molecular sieve capillary column connected to a thermal conductivity detector, while hydrocarbons up to C15 were analyzed using a capillary column with a flame-ionization detector, using a special Agilent application for extended refinery gas detail analysis (GC-SP1 7890–107) Water-gas shift reaction was conducted in a tubular fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure over a temperature range of 200–480 °C, using catalyst grains sized between 0.25–0.50 mm. Approximately 100 mg of each catalyst was loaded into the reactor and activated according to the procedure described earlier. The catalytic activity was evaluated using a reaction mixture with a molar ratio of H2O/CO/N₂ (5/2.5/92.5) at a flow rate yielding a GHSV of 4800 c m 3 g c a t − 1 h − 1 . Reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography, employing a molecular sieve capillary column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (GC-SP1 7890–107). 3 Results 3.1 Catalysts characterization Table 1 presents the labeling, chemical composition, and textural properties of the bare SiO2–Al2O3 support, along with the supported Fe-phosphide and Fe-reference catalysts on SiO2–Al2O3. The theoretical metal loading is indicated in the first column, alongside the sample descriptions. The experimental composition, determined by ICP-AES, closely with the theoretical Fe and P load values, indicating that the desired amount of metal and phosphorous was successfully incorporated. The textural properties of the bare support and freshly reduced catalysts were evaluated through nitrogen physisorption measurements. Fig. 1 shown the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, while Table 1 provides of the SBET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter values of the samples. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the bare support and freshly reduced catalysts are classified as type IV, characteristic of mesoporous materials according to IUPAC standards [32]. The curves display an H3-type hysteresis loop, covering a wide P/P₀ range from 0.6 to 0.9 [33]. The SBET surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume for the bare SA support were 361 m2 g−1, 5.7 nm, and 0.61 cm3 g−1, respectively, values that are within the typical range for this type of support. Following the addition of the active components, a decrease in SBET value was observed. The most noticeable decrease in SSBET value was observed in the Fe-reference catalyst (Fe/SA), which had a surface area of 256 m2 g−1, indicating a 29.1 % reduction. In contrast, the Fe-phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA) exhibited a surface area of 288 m2 g−1, indicating a 20.2 % reduction. Similarly, the largest decrease in pore volume was observed in the Fe/SA catalyst, with a 19.7 % decrement, resulting in a value of 0.49 cm3 g−1. In contrast, the pore volume of the FeP/SA sample decreased by approximately 9.8 %, reaching a value of 0.55 cm3 g−1. The average pore diameter values were similar across the samples, decreasing slightly from 5.7 nm in the bare SA support to 5.5 nm in the FeP/SA catalyst and 5.4 nm in the Fe/SA catalyst. This suggests that the presence of phosphorus appears to preserve the textural properties, as the FeP/SA catalyst exhibited the smallest decrease in these properties compared to the bare SA support. The crystallinity of the bare support and catalysts after activation was investigated by X-ray diffraction. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the bare support and catalysts after activation process. As shown in Fig. 2, all samples exhibit three well-defined diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 37.6°, 45.9°, and 67°, corresponding to the (311), (400), and (440) reflection planes, respectively, which are characteristic of the γ-Al2O3 phase [34,35]. Additionally, the samples showed a broad diffraction peak between 13° and 28° in 2θ, characteristic of the amorphous silica phase [36]. The presence of both SiO2 and Al2O3 crystallographic phases suggests the possible formation of a SiO2-Al2O3 mixed oxide. In addition to the SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 phases, the catalysts displayed additional diffraction peaks (Fig. 2b and 2c). The passivated iron phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA) exhibited three diffraction peaks in 2θ values of 32.7°, 48.3°, and 59.6° (Fig. 2b), corresponding to the (011), (211), and (002) reflection planes, respectively, characteristic to the FeP phase [37,38]. The absence of diffraction peaks corresponding to phosphate, iron oxide, or metallic iron phases suggests that the FeP phase was predominantly formed under the conditions employed in this work. The diffraction patterns of the reference iron catalyst (Fe/SA) in more complex, this exhibited nine diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 24.5°, 34.4°, 39.6°, 41.6°, 44.4°, 47.5°, 50.8°, 58.7° and 65°. The diffraction peaks at 24.5° and 34.4° correspond to the (012) and (104) reflection planes, respectively (Fig. 2c), characteristic of the α-Fe2O3 phase [39]. The diffraction peaks observed at higher 2θ values, 44.4° and 65°, correspond to the (110) and (200) diffraction planes, which are characteristic of metallic iron [40]. The diffraction peaks at 39.6°, 41.6°, 47.5°, 50.8°, 58.7° are characteristics to the diffraction of the Hägg carbide (χ-Fe5C2) phase [41]. However, the diffraction peak at 44.4° is very close to the main diffraction peak of the χ-Fe5C2 phase, which appears around 44.2°. It is possible that this peak represents the superimposed diffractions of both the χ-Fe5C2 phase and metallic iron, and cannot be ruled out. The presence of both oxidized and metallic iron phases indicates that complete activation, including the full formation of the Hägg carbide (χ-Fe5C2 phase), was not fully achieved under the reduction conditions used in this work. However, the intensity of the diffraction peaks associated with the metallic and carbide iron phases is significantly stronger than those of the oxidized iron species, indicating that the majority of the iron species were successfully reduced and activated (Fig. 2c). The surface chemical composition of the activated catalysts was analyzed using XPS. The Si 2p, Al 2p, and O 1 s signals were centered at 103.5 eV, 74.1 eV, and 532.9 eV, respectively [42,43]. Fig. 3a shows the Fe 2p core level spectra and Fig. 3b displays the P 2p core level spectra for the active catalysts. The corresponding core-level binding energies and surface atomic ratios are summarized in Table 2 . For all catalysts, the central C 1 s peak was observed around 284.5 eV, which is characteristic of amorphous carbon [44]. The freshly activated Fe/SA catalysts exhibited an additional C 1 s peak at 283.2 eV (Table 2), accounting for approximately 38 % of the surface carbon species. This peak corresponds to carbidic carbon in the χ-Fe5C2 phase (C−Fe bonds), indicating the formation of Hägg carbide (χ-Fe5C2) as an active site [45]. The Fe 2p3/2 core level peak for the freshly activated Fe-reference catalyst (Fe/SA) exhibits four binding energies at 706.3, 707.6, 709.2, and 710.5 eV (Table 2). The signals at 709.2, and 710.5 eV correspond to Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, respectively [46–48]. This is consistent with the satellite line observed at approximately 717.3 eV, which is a distinct marker of iron oxidized ions [49]. XPS analysis detected Fe2+ species, which were not observed in the XRD results. This suggests that these species may either consist of higher reduced particles that are below the detection limit of the XRD equipment or are part of a mixed iron oxide phase overlying the α-Fe2O3 phase. The Fe 2p3/2 peak at 706.3 eV is indicative of the presence of metallic iron species [50–53], while the signal at 707.6 eV corresponds to the formation of χ-Fe5C2 Hägg carbide active sites. Table 2 shows that approximately 17 % of the iron on the surface is in the Fe0 state, while 41 % corresponds to Fe ions associated with the formation of χ-Fe5C2 active sites. Additionally, 27 % and 15 % are present as oxidized Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, respectively. The presence of these oxidized iron species, as confirmed by the XRD results, suggests that the reference Fe/SA catalyst was not fully reduced or activated (in terms of carbide formation) under the conditions used in this study. For the Fe-phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA), the Fe 2p3/2 core level peak displays only one binding energy at 711.1 eV (Table 2), corresponding to Fe3+ ions, which are associated with the FeP phase [53,54]. Additionally, the spectrum for the FeP/SA catalyst did not show the satellite line at approximately 717.3 eV (Fig. 3a), a distinct marker of oxidized iron ions, suggesting the absence of oxidized iron species. This confirms the formation of the FeP phase, indicating that the Fe3+ species observed in this sample correspond to the FeP phase. The core level spectrum of P 2p for the FeP/SA catalyst is presented in Fig. 3b. Despite interference from the Si plasmon signal at lower binding energies, the P 2p core level spectrum was clearly defined. Two distinct contributions were observed at 128.7 eV and 134.6 eV. The first signal, at 128.7 eV, corresponds to Pδ− species in the iron phosphide phase (Fe3+Pδ−) [31,37], while the second signal, at 134.6 eV, was attributed to phosphorus in the PO4 3− species [34,37], likely formed during the catalyst passivation process. Fe/(Si + Al) atomic surface ratios were calculated from the XPS spectra (Table 2). The iron phosphide catalyst exhibited a higher Fe/(Si + Al) ratio, with 1.3 times more surface iron exposure compared to the reference Fe/SA catalyst. It should be noted that while XPS is a surface-sensitive technique, it analyzes multiple atomic layers of the exposed species, meaning that not all iron sites detected by XPS may correspond to active sites. To better identify the number of potential active iron sites, CO chemisorption was performed (Table 2), assuming that each CO molecule adsorbed onto a single active site [54]. The data indicate that the iron phosphide (FeP)-based catalyst chemisorbs more CO than the Fe-reference catalyst (Fe/SA). The FeP/SA catalyst chemisorbed approximately 1.6 times more CO than the Fe/SA catalyst, suggesting a higher number of adsorption (active) sites on the iron phosphide catalyst. Fig. 4 provides detailed structural and compositional analysis of the active FeP/SA catalyst using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), elemental mapping, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). HRTEM was used to identify a well-defined particle for detailed structural characterization (Fig. 4a). The HRTEM image reveals the formation of a well-crystallized FeP nanoparticle structure supported on the SiO2-Al2O3 support, which has a crystal size of around 5 nm (Fig. 4a). The lattice parameter shows an interplanar spacing of 1.88 Å, corresponding to the (211) plane, which is consistent with the values observed in bulk FeP samples, confirming the formation of the FeP phase. The result is consistent with the peak observed at 48.3° in the 2θ XRD analysis. The surface of the FeP phase is coated with a thin phosphate (PO₄³⁻) layer, approximately 0.7 nm thick (insert in Fig. 4a), resulting from the passivation process, which involves exposing the FeP nanoparticles to a flow containing 0.5 % mol of oxygen diluted in nitrogen at atmospheric temperature, leading to the oxidation of the surface layer. The formation of this phosphate layer is advantageous for the catalyst stability, as it provides strong resistance to further oxidation of the phosphide phase and prevents the formation of undesired phases such as iron carbides or the reversion of FeP to metallic iron. Moreover, the thinness of the phosphate layer suggests that the passivation process was carefully controlled to avoid deep oxidation, ensuring the preservation of the active FeP phase. The TEM image (Fig. 4b) provides a broader view of the FeP/SA catalyst, with yellow arrows highlighting the FeP nanoparticles on the support surface. A relatively uniform distribution of nanoparticles is observed, with an average particle diameter of 4.2 ± 0.2 nm, indicating a high dispersion of the FeP particles on the support. To enable more precise composition mapping of the FeP phase, efforts were focused on locating isolated particles of at least 10 nm in size. Although these larger particles were difficult to find, they typically grow in isolation at the edges of the agglomerated support particles. This minimizes interference from the support, particularly reducing the impact of oxygen from the SiO2-Al2O3 support, allowing for a more accurate compositional analysis. The elemental mapping line image showed in Fig. 4c provides a detailed compositional analysis of the FeP particle, illustrating the distribution of key components, including iron (purple), phosphorus (red), oxygen (blue), and aluminum (green). The mapping line shows that the region of the particle primarily consists of iron and phosphorus, with almost no oxygen present, as evidenced by the absence of blue coloration in that area. The lack of oxygen suggests the successful formation of the FeP phase during synthesis and activation, ensuring the formation of the desired FeP structure. In contrast, the presence of oxygen around the outer edges, highlighted in the blue regions, is likely due to the passivation process. Fig. 4d presents the chemical composition results from two analysis points selected from Fig. 4c. These points were chosen to examine the relative concentrations of the main components, iron (Fe), phosphorus (P), and oxygen (O) within the analyzed particles. The analysis reveals a high concentration of Fe and P, with minimal oxygen detected at both points, confirming the formation of the FeP phase. This indicates that the majority of the particles are composed of well-formed FeP with minimal oxidation. 3.2 Catalytic activity in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis The catalytic activity of the active catalysts during Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, expressed as CO conversion over time on-stream, is presented in Fig. 5 . As shown in this figure, an increase in reaction time led to a decrease in CO conversion during the initial stages of the reaction, as the catalysts during the stabilization step. The greatest activity loss was observed in the Fe/SA catalyst, which initially exhibited a CO conversion of 71.2 % (TOS = 0 h). Over time, its conversion gradually declined, stabilizing after approximately 35 h at 58.2 % CO conversion. In contrast, the iron phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA) experienced a much smaller reduction in catalytic activity during stabilization. It initially achieved a CO conversion of 76.5 % (5.3 % higher than the Fe/SA catalyst) and reached stability much faster, after approximately 12 h, maintaining a stable conversion of 72.3 % (Fig. 5). Overall, the Fe/SA catalyst showed a significant activity loss of around 18 % during catalysts stabilization, while the FeP/SA catalyst only exhibited a modest decrease of about 5.4 %, demonstrating its superior stability (Fig. 5). These results clearly demonstrate that the iron phosphide-based catalyst (FeP/SA) reaches stability in a shorter time and experiences up to 2.6 times less catalytic activity loss during the stabilization stage compared to the reference Fe/SA catalyst. The carbon-based selectivity and hydrocarbon distribution at steady state (TOS = 50 h for the active catalysts are presented in Table 3 . At a TOS of 50 h, the catalysts demonstrated high selectivity for hydrocarbon formation, with the iron phosphide (FeP/SA)-based catalyst achieving the highest selectivity at 78.8 %, compared to 68.2 % of hydrocarbon for the Fe/SA catalyst. Conversely, the Fe/SA catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity for CO2 formation at 31.5 %, while the FeP/SA catalyst showed a significant reduction in CO2 formation, with a selectivity of 20.6 %. Low CO2 selectivity in FeP catalysts as the active phase was previously reported by Y. Jingh et al. [30]. Their study evaluated the FeP phase in both bulk FeP and supported FeP on graphene oxide. They observed a CO2 selectivity of 7.3 % for the bulk FeP catalyst, which further decreased to 6.2 % when graphene oxide was employed as the support for the FeP active phase. Both catalysts displayed low selectivity for oxygenated compounds, with the FeP/SA catalyst reaching 0.6 % and the Fe/SA catalyst at 0.3 %. The nature of the active site plays a crucial role in influencing product selectivity during FTS. The iron phosphide phase significantly reduced CO2 selectivity by up to 34.6 % compared to the Fe/SA reference catalyst. Additionally, the iron phosphide-based catalyst increased hydrocarbon selectivity by 15.5 % compared to the Fe/SA catalyst. The hydrocarbon distribution shows significant differences between the Fe/SA and FeP/SA catalysts during FTS (Table 3). Notably, the FeP/SA catalyst exhibits a more favorable product distribution compared to the Fe/SA catalyst. The FeP/SA catalyst exhibits lower methane selectivity (23.4 %) compared to the Fe/SA catalyst (27.1 %). This reduction in methane production is advantageous, as methane is an undesired byproduct in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The use of iron phosphide has also been associated with low selectivity toward methane formation. Y. Jingh et al. [30] reported a methane selectivity of 19.5 % for the FeP active phase supported on graphene oxide (FeP/G), compared to 33.2 % for the bulk FeP phase. The authors attributed the reduced methane selectivity of FeP/G to the smaller particle size of the active phase and the electron-conducting properties of graphene oxide, which may influence catalytic performance. Additionally, the total selectivity for the light hydrocarbons fraction (C2 C4, including olefins and paraffins) is higher with the FeP/SA catalyst (46.4 %) than with the Fe/SA catalyst (32.3 %), indicating that the iron phosphide phase enhances light hydrocarbon formation. Analyzing the light hydrocarbons fraction, the most significant difference is observed in the production of light olefins (C2 =- C4 =). The FeP/SA catalyst achieves higher selectivity for light olefin formation, reaching 31.5 %, compared to 19.5 % for the Fe/SA catalyst. This improvement is reflected in the O/P (Olefin/Paraffin) ratio, where the FeP/SA catalyst shows a higher ratio of 2.1, compared to 1.5 for the Fe/SA catalyst. This indicates a stronger preference for olefin formation over paraffin formation, which is particularly advantageous for applications that target light olefins, as they are more valuable as chemical feedstocks. High selectivity for light hydrocarbons, particularly with a high olefinic fraction on FeP phase, was also reported by Y. Jingh et al. [30]. The authors observed an olefin-to-paraffin (O/P) ratio of up to 1.7 for FeP supported on graphene oxide. This enhanced selectivity was attributed to the exceptional conductivity of graphene, which promotes the formation of adsorbed species with low chemical potential. This, in turn, facilitates the desorption of olefinic compounds, thereby limiting further hydrogenation and reducing paraffin formation. In contrast, the FeP/SA catalyst exhibits lower selectivity toward heavier hydrocarbons (C5⁺), at 30.2 %, compared to 40.6 % for the Fe/SA catalyst. This reduction in heavy hydrocarbon formation aligns with the increased production of lighter olefins and suggests that the iron phosphide phase helps limit excessive chain growth. In summary, using the iron phosphide phase as an active catalyst enhances selectivity for light olefin formation, significantly reduces methane and heavy hydrocarbon production, and lowers CO2 output. These factors make the iron phosphide phase an effective catalyst for synthesizing light olefins through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. 4 Discussion XRD and XPS analyses revealed the presence of only the FeP phase in the FeP/SA catalyst, while the Fe/SA catalyst contained metallic and oxidized iron, along with iron carbide (χ-Fe5C2) phases. The well-formed FeP phase in the FeP/SA catalyst was further confirmed by HRTEM results. The FeP/SA catalyst exhibited higher and more stable CO conversion over time due to the greater stability of the FeP phase, which resists deactivation. In contrast, the Fe/SA catalyst showed a rapid decrease in CO conversion. The higher deactivation of the Fe/SA catalyst could be attributed to changes in the composition of the active phase. To investigate the causes of catalyst deactivation, we characterized spent catalysts after 78 h of time-on-stream. N2 physisorption analysis revealed a decrease in SBET values in both catalysts after reaction, compared to the fresh, reduced samples. The iron-based catalyst (Fe/SA) showed an SBET value of 198 m2 g−1, representing a 22 % reduction from its freshly activated state (256 m2 g−1). In contrast, the FeP/SA catalyst exhibited an SBET value of 259 m2 g−1after reaction, compared to 288 m2 g−1 before reaction, indicating a 10 % decrease. The greater surface area loss observed for Fe/SA suggests structural changes and probable carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. In comparison, the FeP/SA catalyst demonstrated a smaller decrease in surface area, suggesting lower coke deposition or active phase sintering, which may contribute to its reduced catalytic activity loss. The spent catalysts after 78 h of FTS reaction was analyzed using X-ray diffraction by XRD. The XRD patterns of the spent catalysts following the reaction are presented in Fig. 6 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 37.6°, 45.9°, and 67° correspond to the (311), (400), and (440) planes of the γ-Al2O3 phase [34,35], confirming that the gamma alumina structure remains even after reaction. Additionally, a broad diffraction peak between 13° and 28° in 2θ, characteristic of the amorphous silica phase [36], is also observed. The spent iron phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA) displayed diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 32.7°, 48.3°, and 59.6° (Fig. 6a), corresponding to the (011), (211), and (002) planes, which are characteristic of the FeP phase [37,38]. Notably, no diffraction peaks corresponding to iron oxide species, iron phosphates, or iron carbides are observed, suggesting that the iron phosphide phase is stable during the FTS reaction. However, the potential formation of these phases cannot be ruled out, as their particle sizes may be below the detection limit of the X-ray source used. Unlike the diffraction patterns of the reference iron catalyst (Fe/SA) before the catalytic reaction, the diffraction patterns of the spent Fe/SA catalyst no longer exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks of the metallic iron phase (44.4° and 65° in 2θ, Fig. 6b). This observation suggests that the metallic iron was transformed into other iron-containing phases during the reaction. Furthermore, the Fe/SA catalyst after the reaction (Fig. 6b) displayed a slight decrease in the intensity of the diffraction peaks associated with the Hägg carbide phase (χ-Fe5C2) at 39.6°, 41.6°, 47.5°, 50.8°, and 58.7° in 2θ, compared to its state prior to the FTS reaction (Fig. 2c). This indicates a possible reduction in the proportion or crystallinity of the χ-Fe5C2 phase after the reaction. As the χ-Fe5C2 phase decreased and the metallic iron peaks disappeared in the Fe/SA catalyst after the reaction (Fig. 6b), a significant increase in the fraction of iron oxide species was observed. The intensity of the diffraction peaks associated with oxidized iron species is notably higher than those of the iron carbide phases, indicating significant reoxidation of the metallic iron species, as well as the active χ-Fe5C2 phase, occurred during the FTS process (Fig. 6b). The spent catalyst, following the FTS reaction, was analyzed using transmission electron microscopy. The HRTEM image (Fig. 7a ) reveals a well-crystallized FeP phase with an interplanar spacing of 1.88 Å, corresponding to the (211) plane, which confirms the presence of the FeP phase even after 78 h of FTS reaction. This observation aligns with the XRD results obtained for the same sample. Also a phosphate (PO4 3⁻) layer was observed covering the surface of the iron phosphide phase on the spent FeP/SA catalyst after the reaction (Fig. 7b). The thickness of this layer increased to approximately 0.84 nm, representing a growth of 0.14 nm compared to the pre-reaction layer (Fig. 3a). This increase suggests slight oxidation of the phosphorus species during the FTS reaction. Additionally, the post-reaction phosphate layer exhibited low crystallinity, which likely explains the absence of characteristic diffraction peaks associated with phosphate species. Similar to the previous microscopy analysis (Fig. 4c), a large, and isolated agglomerated particle was analyzed for elemental mapping to reduce chemical interference from the support, ensuring a more precise compositional analysis. The elemental mapping line image in Fig. 7c illustrates the distribution of key elements: iron (violet), phosphorus (blue), oxygen (red), and aluminum (green). The mapping reveals that the central region of the particle predominantly consists of iron and phosphorus (violet and blue lines), with a negligible presence of oxygen (red line). This absence of oxygen in the core region strongly indicates that the FeP phase remains well-preserved even after the FTS reaction. The TEM image (Fig. 7d) provides a broader view of the FeP/SA catalyst, with yellow arrows highlighting the FeP nanoparticles on the support surface. A relatively uniform distribution of nanoparticles is observed, with an average particle diameter of 4.6 ± 0.3 nm, indicating a high dispersion of the FeP particles on the support. These results suggest that the FeP phase exhibits exceptional resistance to sintering, reoxidation, and carburization during the FTS reaction. To investigate the stability of the active phase, we conducted XPS studies of the samples post-reaction. Fig. 8a shows the Fe 2p core level spectra and Fig. 8b displays the C 1 s core level spectra for spent catalysts after FTS at TOS of 78 h. The corresponding core-level binding energies and surface atomic ratios are summarized in Table 4 . The Fe 2p3/2 core level peak for the spent Fe/SA catalysts after FTS at TOS of 78 exhibits only three binding energies at 707.7, 709.2, and 710.6 eV (Table 4). The signals at 709.2 and 710.6 eV are attributed to oxidized iron species [46–48], corresponding to the presence of a satellite line observed in the spectra [49]. The signal at 707.6 eV corresponds to the formation of χ-Fe5C2 Hägg carbide active sites [50–52]. This is confirmed by the C1 s signal at 283.5 eV (Table 4), which is characteristic of carbon species associated with the carbide phase [45]. The signal corresponding to metallic iron species was absent in the spent Fe/SA catalyst after 78 h of reaction, although this signal at 706.3 eV was present in the freshly activated samples prior to the FTS reaction (Table 2). Furthermore, we can see that the fraction of oxidized iron species increased after the FTS reaction, while a decrease was observed in the fraction of iron species associated with the phase of the χ-Fe5C2 Hägg carbide (Similar observations were made in the XRD analysis of the catalysts after the reaction, Fig. 6b). The fraction of iron species associated with the χ-Fe5C2 phase decreased from approximately 41 % before the FTS reaction (Table 2) to 29 % after 78 h of reaction (Table 4). The Fe/SA catalyst showed a decrease in iron carbide active sites (χ-Fe5C2), which transformed into oxidized species, while metallic iron underwent complete oxidation during the FTS process. This reoxidation of iron, as indicated by the increase in Fe2+ and Fe3+ species observed in the XPS results, contributed to the catalyst's loss of activity. The reoxidation of iron species during FTS is a key factor leading to the observed deactivation. For the spent Fe-phosphide catalyst (FeP/SA) after 78 h of FTS, the Fe 2p3/2 core level peak shows three binding energies at 709.1, 710.4, and 711.1 eV (Table 4). The signals at 709.1 and 710.4 eV are attributed to oxidized iron species [56–57], while the signal at 711.1 eV corresponds to Fe3+ ions associated with the FeP phase [53,54]. The P 2p signals at 128.7 eV and 134.6 eV correspond to Pδ− species in the iron phosphide phase and phosphorus in the PO4 3− species, likely formed during the catalyst passivation process [31,37]. It is noteworthy that the iron phosphide-based catalyst (FeP/SA) exhibited oxidized iron species after 78 h of reaction, with only about 11 % of the iron species undergoing oxidation during FTS reaction (Table 4), indicating lower oxidation of the Fe species. Similarly, a slight increase in phosphorus species associated with the phosphate phase was observed, while the phosphorus species linked to the phosphide phase showed a slight decrease of approximately 5 %. In contrast, the Fe/SA catalyst exhibited 71 % oxidized iron species after the FTS reaction (Table 4), marking a 29 % increase in the fraction of oxidized iron species over the 78-hour period compared to the freshly activated catalyst prior to the reaction (Table 2). The Fe/SA catalyst shows a decrease in the iron species related to carbide active sites (χ-Fe5C2), which were transformed into oxidized species (less activity), while metallic iron underwent complete reoxidation during the FTS process, which as indicated by the increase in Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, observed by XPS results. In contrast, the FeP phase exhibited greater resistance to iron species reoxidation, maintaining a higher proportion of iron phosphide sites throughout the reaction. These results suggest that the iron phosphide phase demonstrates better resistance to the reoxidation of iron species during the FTS reaction, compared to the phosphorus-free catalyst (As suggested by XRD analysis of the catalysts after the reaction). A schematic representation of CO dissociative adsorption, which could lead to the reoxidation of iron species and CO2 formation, is illustrated in Scheme 1, adapted from references [55,56]. The direct hydrogenation mechanism of adsorbed CO and the subsequent hydrocarbon chain growth not ruled out. Based on our results, it is plausible that the reoxidation of iron species and CO2 formation occur via a CO dissociation-adsorption mechanism on the catalyst surface, contributing to overall CO2 production alongside the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction. In the first stage, CO is adsorbed onto the surface (Scheme 1a), followed by the dissociative adsorption of carbon and oxygen atoms (Scheme 1b). This gives rise to two reasonable pathways for oxygen removal and a possible route for iron reoxidation. One pathway involves the oxidation of adsorbed hydrogen with dissociated oxygen, leading to the formation of water, which is subsequently desorbed (Scheme 1c). Another pathway involves the oxidation of an adsorbed CO molecule with dissociated oxygen, forming CO2 (Scheme 1d), which is then desorbed, explaining CO2 formation. A third possibility is that adsorbed oxygen interacts with surface iron species, leading to their partial reoxidation (Scheme 1e), which explains the reoxidation of iron during the FTS reaction. To evaluate the contribution of the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction in the CO2 formationof each of the catalysts (iron phosphide phase compared to its iron-based counterpart), the WGS reaction were conducted under contact time conditions similar to those used in this study. Fig. 9 illustrates the CO conversion as a function of temperature during the WGS reaction, showing an increase in CO conversion with rising temperatures. The Fe/SA catalyst demonstrated consistently higher CO to CO2 conversion across the entire temperature range studied. At 280 °C (the reaction temperature used in the FTS experiments), the Fe/SA catalyst achieved a CO conversion of 5.5 %, whereas the iron phosphide-based catalyst (FeP/SA) reached only 1.6 %. This indicates that the Fe/SA catalyst is approximately 3.3 times more active than the FeP/SA catalyst in the WGS reaction. These results suggest that the WGS reaction contributes minimally to CO2 formation on the FeP/SA catalyst. Consequently, it is plausible to assume that CO2 formation on this catalyst primarily occurs through the oxidation of an adsorbed CO molecule with dissociated oxygen, as illustrated in Scheme 1d. In contrast, the Fe/SA catalyst exhibits a more significant contribution from the WGS reaction to CO2 formation, indicating that this mechanism plays a key role in CO2 generation on the Fe/SA catalyst. However, further experiments are needed to clarify the exact contributions of these reaction pathways, principality on the Fe/SA catalyst. It should be noted that the deactivation mechanisms are more complex and could also be associated with the surface coverage by coke deposited. The formation of coke can be investigated through the analysis of the C 1 s peak using XPS. Prior to XPS analysis, the samples were treated at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of 200 cm3 min−1 of ultra-high purity nitrogen to remove volatile and adsorbed compounds. XPS analysis of the C 1 s core level was performed to identify surface-adsorbed carbon species formed under FTS conditions. The C 1 s core-level spectra, shown in Fig. 8b, display binding energies at 284.5, 285.1, 286.1, and 288.3 eV. The BE peaks at 284.5, 285, and 288.3 eV correspond to CC or CC, CH, and OCO bonds, respectively [57–60], while the signal at 286.1 eV is attributed to CO, COC, and COH bonds [57–60]. The peaks at 285.1, 286.1, and 288.1 eV are associated with surface carbon species CO, OCO, and CH groups, suggesting the formation of coke on the surface. To provide an accurate analysis of the carbon species present on the catalyst surface after the reaction, the carbon fraction corresponding to the iron carbide phase (approximately 19 %, as observed in the Fe/SA catalyst, see Table 4) was excluded. As a result, the Fe/SA sample exhibited up to 35 % surface carbon species associated with CO, OCO, and CH groups (groups related to coke formation), while the iron phosphide-based catalyst showed only 20 % of carbon species related to these groups. The phosphide-based catalyst has shown significantly higher resistance to coke formation, producing up to 1.85 times less coke than the Fe/SA catalyst. This enhanced resistance to coke formation on the surface of the iron phosphide-based catalyst also contributes to its superior catalytic stability over extended time-on-stream. The presence of coke on the surface of the spent catalysts was confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy. Prior to analysis, the spent catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C for 1 hour under a flow of ultra-high purity Ar (99.999 %) to eliminate retained oligomers, hydrocarbons, and surface-adsorbed water. Fig. 10a highlights the 1750–1300 cm−1 region of the FTIR spectra, where typical bending vibrations of aromatic and aliphatic carbons are observed [61–63]. Four distinct signals appear at 1615, 1510, 1462, and 1380 cm−1. Additionally, a lower-intensity band at 1577 cm−1 is observed for the reference Fe/SA catalyst. The signal at 1615 cm−1 is attributed to the CC stretching vibration of olefins or alkylbenzenes, while the 1577 cm−1 signal corresponds to the CC stretching in polycyclic aromatic rings. Additionally, the 1510 cm−1 signal is linked to the CC stretching in alkylbenzene rings, indicating the presence of hard coke [61]. The bands at 1462 and 1380 cm−1, characteristic of soft coke, are attributed to CH2- bending in the CC stretching of aromatic rings and CH bending in alkylbenzenes, respectively [61–63]. The reference Fe/SA catalyst exhibits the highest FTIR absorption intensity across all bands, except at 1380 cm−1, when compared to the FeP/SA catalyst. Additionally, the Fe/SA catalyst shows stronger signals for bands associated with hard coke (1615, 1577, and 1510 cm−1) than those linked to soft coke (1462 and 1380 cm−1). This suggests that hard coke is the predominant type of present on the surface of the reference Fe/SA catalyst. In contrast, the relative area of the FTIR bands associated with soft coke was slightly larger than those characteristics of hard coke, suggesting that the phosphide phase may inhibit hard coke formation compared to the reference catalyst. This finding aligns with the observations from the XPS analysis. To quantify the carbon content and types of carbon species deposited on the catalyst surfaces, TGA/DTA analysis was performed on the spent catalysts over a temperature range of 200 °C to 1100 °C. Before analysis, the used catalysts were pretreated under an ultra-high purity Ar flow (99.999 %) at 500 °C for 1 hour to remove retained oligomers, hydrocarbons, and adsorbed water from the surface. The weight loss and DTA profiles for the representative catalysts are displayed in Fig. 10b and 10c, respectively. Following thermal treatment, the observed weight loss is attributed to the combustion of coke-like carbon species, with mass loss beginning around 400 °C (Fig. 10b). Consistent with the literature [64,65], the Fe/SA reference catalyst exhibited significantly higher mass loss due to coke combustion (11.3 %) compared to the FeP/SA catalyst, which showed a lower mass loss (5.6 %) (Fig. 10b). The greater coke amount on the Fe/SA catalyst surface may explain its larger decrease in SBET value (22 %) after 78 h under reaction conditions. The type of coke formed on the catalyst surface can be inferred from the DTA profiles shown in Fig. 10c. All catalysts displayed peaks in the DTA profile at 544–560 °C, 770 °C, and 823–840 °C. As anticipated, the Fe/SA reference catalyst exhibited intense peaks attributed to coke combustion, with the more graphitic coke indicated by peaks at higher temperatures [64,65]. Notably, the DTA peak intensities were much lower for the FeP/SA catalyst. Additionally, the FeP/SA catalyst showed a DTA peak distribution where the peaks at higher temperatures (770–840 °C), corresponding to more graphitized coke, were slightly higher than the peak at 544 °C, associated with less graphitic carbon species. In contrast, the Fe/SA reference catalyst had higher-intensity peaks at the higher temperatures, suggesting enhanced formation of hard, graphitized coke species on its surface. This indicates that the FeP phase may inhibit soft coke formation and reduce the degree of graphitization in the carbon species (hard coke). These observations align with the FTIR and C1 s XPS results, suggesting that the FeP phase effectively inhibits coke formation and reduces the accumulation of more complex coke species (hard coke) on the surface. Another factor that could contribute to the higher activity loss observed in the Fe/SA reference catalyst, compared to the iron phosphide-based catalyst, may be the reduced number of exposed iron sites on the surface after the reaction. This limited availability of active sites could explain the catalysts diminished catalytic activity over reaction time. In Table 2 (before reaction), the Fe/(Si + Al) ratio for the Fe/SA catalyst is 0.037, while for the FeP/SA catalyst, it is 0.048. After the reaction, as seen in Table 4, these ratios decrease to 0.029 for Fe/SA and 0.046 for FeP/SA. The reduction in the amount of exposed iron species on the surface could be attributed to a decrease in dispersion or the partial coverage of a fraction of the iron species by coke formed during the reaction. However, the decrease in Fe species surface exposure is less in the FeP/SA catalyst, indicating that the phosphide phase has better resistance during the FTS reaction. In contrast, the Fe/SA catalyst exhibits a more significant reduction in exposed iron species, suggesting lower stability of the surface iron species on this sample throughout the FTS reaction. The superior stability of the FeP catalyst and its enhanced selectivity for olefins in FTS can be attributed to its remarkable resistance to reoxidation and coke formation, two common deactivation pathways in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. This stability enables FeP to maintain a higher proportion of active sites over extended reaction times, ensuring consistent CO conversion and catalytic activity. In contrast, non-phosphide iron catalysts are more susceptible to oxidation and iron carbide formation, both of which lead to deactivation and reduced catalytic performance. Finally, the phosphide iron catalyst favored the formation of light olefins (C2⁻ - C4⁻) while reducing the production of methane (CH4) and heavier hydrocarbons (C5⁺), unlike Fe/SA, which produced higher amounts of methane and heavier hydrocarbons. Additionally, the phosphide iron catalyst exhibited significantly lower CO2 selectivity, indicating reduced water-gas shift (WGS) activity or the oxidation of CO by surface-absorbed oxygen resulting from direct CO dissociation on the surface, compared to Fe/SA. Both catalysts displayed low selectivity toward oxygenates, with FeP/SA showing slightly higher oxygenate formation. The enhanced formation of olefinic compounds over the FeP phase during FTS, particularly light olefins (C2 −-C4 −), can be related to electronic character of the iron ions into of the FeP phase, which differ significantly from those of traditional iron based catalysts. Phosphorus in the FeP phase lattice contributes to increasing the electron density around iron, resulting in an enhanced metallic character of the Fe ions, compared with the traditional iron based catalyst [19–21]. In the FeP phase lattice, the phosphorus atoms are reported to be weakly basic and negatively charged, playing a crucial role in promoting the desorption of molecules [66]. On one hand, the metallic character of the iron ions in the FeP phase enhances CO adsorption and activation as well as H2 dissociation. On the other hand, the negatively charged phosphorus ions facilitate the desorption of formed molecules by moderating the bonding strength of intermediates on the catalyst surface. This dual functionality favors the formation of lower molecular weight molecules and less saturated hydrocarbons (olefins), both critical for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. These results highlight the superior performance of iron phosphide-based catalysts (FeP/SA) in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, showcasing enhanced stability, higher selectivity toward light olefins, and reduced formation of methane and CO2 compared to traditional Fe/SA catalysts. These findings suggest that iron phosphide-based catalysts present a viable alternative for more efficient and sustainable hydrocarbon production through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. 5 Conclusions XRD and XPS analyses confirmed the presence of the FeP phase in the FeP/SA catalyst, while the Fe/SA catalyst exhibited a mixture of metallic, oxidized iron species and Hägg iron carbide phase (χ-Fe5C2). The phosphide-based catalyst (FeP/SA) showed higher CO conversion and has demonstrated significantly greater stability during Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, compared to the Fe/SA catalyst. This enhanced stability is attributed to the FeP phase resistance to both iron species reoxidation and coke formation over extended periods of FTS reaction, in contrast to the reference Fe/SA catalyst. The iron FeP/SA catalyst demonstrated enhanced selectivity towards the formation of light olefins fraction (C2⁻ – C4⁻), which are valuable for industrial applications, while simultaneously reducing the formation of undesirable methane and heavier hydrocarbons. Moreover, FeP/SA exhibited lower CO2 formation, indicating reduced water-gas shift (WGS) activity or the oxidation of CO by surface-absorbed oxygen resulting from direct CO dissociation on the surface, compared to Fe/SA. XPS results further confirmed minimal oxidation of iron species in FeP/SA, in contrast to significant oxidation observed in the Fe/SA catalyst. These findings suggest that iron phosphide-based catalysts offer a promising option for improving the efficiency of light olefin hydrocarbon production through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Here reports preliminary results on the performance of iron phosphide-based catalysts supported on SiO2-Al2O3 (denoted as SA) for sustainable light olefin production via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, compared to conventional iron-based catalysts. Characterization results confirmed the presence of a well-defined FeP phase in the iron phosphide-based catalysts (FeP/SA), whereas the iron-based catalysts (Fe/SA) displayed a mixture of metallic iron (Fe0), oxidized iron (Fe+2/Fe+3), and Hägg iron carbide phase (χ-Fe5C2). The FeP/SA catalyst exhibited significantly higher CO conversion and stability over long reaction times, attributed to its resistance to surface iron species reoxidation, lower loss of exposed surface Fe species, and lower coke formation during the FTS reaction. The FeP/SA catalyst exhibited higher selectivity toward light olefins formation (C2 ⁻- C4 ⁻), while reducing selectivity for methane (CH4) and heavier hydrocarbon formation compared to the Fe/SA catalyst. Furthermore, FeP/SA exhibited lower selectivity to CO2 formation, which may indicate reduced water-gas shift (WGS) activity or the oxidation of adsorbed CO by surface-bound oxygen, resulting from the direct dissociation of CO on the surface, compared to Fe/SA catalyst. These results suggest that iron phosphide-based catalysts provide an efficient alternative for hydrocarbon production in FTS, particularly in the selective formation of light olefins.
